Statistics for Life and Social Sciences

STAD29/STA429/STA1007 Ken Butler
     
D29 home page
  
  • Lectures: Monday 12:00-13:00 in AA209 and Wednesday 13:00-14:00 in AC 334. Or so I thought. The registrar's website says AC334 both days, so we will meet there on Monday Jan 5.
  • Instructor: Ken Butler
  • Office: H417 (but don't expect to find the instructor there other than on lecture days)
  • E-mail: butler (at) utsc dot utoronto dot ca (you can figure it out, can't you?)
  • Office hours: to be announced, but probably before or after class. E-mail will reach me at any time if you need to get in touch.
  • Text: I am not going to make you buy a text, but the one by Tabachnick and Fidell seems to match my philosophy for this course, and may well be a source of examples and ideas for me. If you want a text, this is the one to go for. You might also like to look at Jerry Brunner's online text: see the bottom of this page. 
  • Prerequisites: for undergrads, the sequence STAB22 - STAB27 (or the St George sequence STA220-STA221). For grad students, you'll need a first course followed by some training in regression and ANOVA (or be prepared to do some self-study in the first couple of weeks of class).
  • Exclusions: this course is not meant for Statistics majors. It is for students in other fields who wish to learn some more advanced statistical methods. The exclusions in the Calendar reflect this.
  • Topics: some or all of the following, depending on time and interest (I'm happy to be flexible) 
    • review of statistical inference (tests and confidence intervals) using two-sample t-test
    • review of multiple regression
    • logistic regression
    • multivariate analysis of variance (including a brief review of ANOVA)
    • discriminant analysis
    • cluster analysis
    • principal components
    • factor analysis
    • repeated measures
    • survival analysis
  • Computing: this is a big part of the course, and is not optional. I will be expecting you to demonstrate that you are able to use the computer package SAS to analyze data according to the topics learned, and to critically interpret the output. Most of our class time will be spent on this, in fact. No prior knowledge of SAS is assumed: we start from ground zero.
  • Grading: there will be a short (2 hour) final exam, but no midterm. There will be assignments every week or two. For undergrads, the grade will be based on these two things. Graduate students will also be required to complete a project using one or more of the techniques learned in class, on a dataset from their field of study. 
    For undergrads, the final exam is worth 30% and the assignments (equally weighted) 70%; for grad students, the final exam is also worth 30%, the assignments are worth 35% and the project 35%. I would like to know what you have in mind for your project; please discuss your plans with me somewhere around week 6. Projects will be due at the last class of the semester.
  • Plagiarism: you are reminded that any work that you hand in, or otherwise claim as your own, cannot be copied from anyone else. I am very sensitive to things I've seen before, so be warned. It is fine  to discuss the assignments and to learn from each other, but it is not fine to look at anyone else's output.
